conversations.content: A Kind Dragon's Hopes: Part One
The dragon Mercury once lived in the ocean, but after gaining four limbs, she rose from the sea and supported  the development of a new town.
That town's name was Saint Lotier, and from a tall hill with a magnificent view, she watched over both it and its residents.
But alas, the town's development was fraught with troubles. There were natural disasters like floods, but also countless invasions from other neighboring countries.
Mercury used the power of water to keep the town safe, and over the next century, Saint Lotier developed into one of the most important cities on the entire continent.
It became a land of water—vast and beautiful—and the dragon treasured it above all else.
In Mercury's compassionate heart, she began to think of the city like her own child, and decided there was nothing she would not do to ensure its continuing safety.
But one day, a dark-hearted soul hatched a plot to use that very kindness to manipulate her.

title: A Kind Dragon's Hopes: Part One (210040011)

conversations.content: A Kind Dragon's Hopes: Part Two
Mercury watched over the Aquapolis and thought of it like her own child— all the while unaware that someone had dark ambitions to turn this very love against her.
＂Are you sure of this, Harle?＂ ＂I am, Master Emile. The dragon is fixated with Saint Lotier. If we use that fact to our advantage, she will have no choice but to obey us.＂
＂Excellent! Er, how do we do that?＂ ＂I have a cunning plan. Listen well...＂
Advised by his subordinate Harle, Prince Emile came before Mercury and attempted to enlist her aid.
＂I am the sixth scion of the Kingdom of Alberia,＂ said Emile, ＂and you WILL form a pact with me, Waterwyrm!＂ ＂No,＂ responded Mercury. ＂I will never leave this land.＂
＂If concern for this land keeps you here, that is all the more reason to form a pact with me!＂ cackled Emile. ＂What are you implying?＂ asked Mercury with growing alarm.
＂My spies inform me that this city will soon come under attack by an enemy nation with a thousand ships!＂
＂I fear not invasion,＂ said Mercury. ＂Countless have tried to date, and I have repelled them all.＂
＂And what if I said this foe will use impure fiends to do their bidding—fiends whose mana will pollute this beautiful sea of yours long after their deaths!＂
＂Ah, but I can keep this city safe,＂ continued Emile. ＂I will use the power of my kingdom to force peace with these people and stop the invasion... but only if you join me in a pact.＂
After much thought, Mercury chose to form a pact, putting the safety and prosperity of her child above all else.
Later, Mercury learned that Emile was not fit to form a pact with her, and so she chose to form one with Euden instead.
As she spent her long days at the Halidom, Mercury often found herself thinking of Saint Lotier. Was it safe? How did its people fare?
But despite this, she did not regret even for a moment forming a pact with Euden.
For though she worried for her city in the short term, she believed in the future of peace and prosperity that Euden sought.
